title: Essential
comment: Once you get past the learning curve this app does almost everything you'll need it to do. It's Open Source and it allows one to randomize all their passwords and access them in one place without ever needing to know more than one password. Best used in tandem with the desktop version. My only gripe is that if I access a backup .kdb file from my phone it will be read-only. This means my master database has to be created on my phone if I want it to be editable. A small gripe. Download and donate!

title: UI is simple and easy!
comment: Please do not change the UI! Simple straight, forward, clean and un-bloated! My main is a 56-bit and can handle 128-bit or more(?) unlike the "pretty" bloatware everyone else has! Don't listen to the naysayers who like the "oh it's not pretty" type of apps! You don't find simple, rock solid apps anymore! Only a massive brute force can even attempt access so love this security app!!! Loyal Tier3 fan! Bkups to PC is a copy paste. Simple! No need to sync, it's an unsecured transfer...

title: Gets the job done, missing some modern aspects.
comment: The most convenient want to keep your database in sync with your other systems is via cloud storage. While Dropbox's functionality allows for KeepassDroid to work well with it, lack of Storage Access Framework (SAF) support means most other cloud providers (even Google Drive) don't work. Additionally, the design is dated.  This app needs SAF support to handle most cloud providers, and could really use an influx of material design. Docking 1-star for each issue until resolved.

Do not name the shared folder Password, or anything like that... There may be a time when somebody gains access to a share through a device, or malware.

title: Works great, compatible with KeePassX
comment: I use KeePassX on my laptop and have a key file on a removable memory card. When I downloaded this app I copied my keepass .kdb file from my memory card to the microSD card in my phone and told KeePassDroid where it was, entered my master password and instantly had access to all my KeePassX passwords. It's MUCH more secure than trying to come up with passwords any other way and I've yet to have any online account of mine hacked to my knowledge. If you use KeePass on any other platform it should work seamlessly.

title: Great app, has served me well for years, but K2A is my new default
comment: I've used this app for years, and found it an absolutely invaluable portable password manager, especially when used with dropbox/equivalent.  The strongest virtues of this app are it's full read/write support for kp1 and kp2 databases.   However lack of updates and improvements have meant that Keepass2Android Password Safe has overtaken it in terms of general functionality and in terms of UI.  While many will stick to KeePassDroid for it's simplicity and full read/write for all both database versions  K2A has a cleaner easier to read UI, and optional integrated cloud hosting functionality, meaning you can view the latest file straight from Any cloud service you wish (I use Google Drive).  I shall continue to use this app for writing to kdb files.

comment: My only issue so far is that I cannot open up my KeePass database 2.x file DIRECTLY from my Microsoft SkyDrive ("cloud") system. Once there, it's very intuitive and straight forward and I love the option to right click on the top corner to Copy Username, as well as Copy Password in addition to highlighting the password with my finger then copying it.  With that said, I give 4 Stars (if they can fix the issue of opening up the files directly from SkyDrive, then I will upgraded to 5 stars).  Now being that this app is FREE....I actually will "Donate" to them (as well as their desktop version) as this is something VERY important and useful that allows me to keep track of all my passwords, now that I have used their strong password generator as well as their powerful encryption of the database file.  Open Source is truly the way to go for this.  Phone: Motorola DROID RAZR MAXX HD O/S: Android 4.1.1 (JellyBean) Carrier: Verizon

title: Unintelligent
comment: You start it for the first time and it asks to "enter database filename" and points at /storage/emulated/0/keepass/keepass.kdb with the options to "Open" or "Create". A: my file is not a KDB, it's a KDBX format, B: it's not stored in that search path. Meaning "Open" button won't work, only "Create" will work, which will create the named file in the specified location. And C: tapping the folder icon asks to complete the action with Drive or Dropbox. So you can't browse for local files, it only understands cloud locations. So to locate a local file you have to know the search path and file name beforehand and type it in and tap "Open". It's the same with specifying key file locations, it only understands Drive and Dropbox locations. Once you open the file, it works OK. But support for KDBX is only Beta. And database settings are grayed out, not available. If you clear app data and start over, and choose to "Create" a new KDB file at default location (above) it just stares at you. In case you already created that KDB before and it's stored at location... it doesn't prompt you to overwrite it, it doesn't even tell you why it's not doing anything like "sorry, the file is already there".

Also syncs with DropBox.  To sync the database from a computer to phone with the desktop software, just connect phone with USB cord, open your phone, find the app, open it and then request import.    I've upgraded my review to 5 Stars.  Couldn't live without this app syncing with DropBox.  A lifesaver!  For people who think it doesn't sync from their phone it does.  Just save it to your SD card now it will sync.  If you save it elsewhere it will not.

title: 2.x database
comment: Keepass has had the 2.x database format out for some time (years).  Keepassdroid only supports 1.x databases in read\write and 2.x in read only.  What this means is that if you want to update your pc to the latest keepass, your can't change anything on your droid, since the db is read only.  That is a deal breaker for me.  I need the ability to update passwords from both platforms and keep them synced.  Keepass 1.x is still available for your pc but there is no guarantee that will continue.

title: Perfect for v1 Keypass
comment: I have been using KeePass v1 for years. It is an outstanding product, but its sync function with Keypass Portable on a USB messagestick has always been rather primitive (just copy the file from one place to the other). If you happen to add or change a password on different accounts on both the PC and the message stick, getting them sync'd can be quite tricky.  KeePassDroid avoids this problem for the PC/Android phone situation quite nicely.  I don't know v2, so I don't know why there is a 2-way problem for kdbx files, but for V1 kdb files this is a great 2-way solution.

title: Won't recognize my password
comment: So, I installed the app, set my main password and entered a ton of password information for bills, websites, emails for probably over 30 accounts. Exited and was happy with all my setups. I went to retrieve a password for a bill website and when I entered my main password for the keepass file, it said I had the wrong password. I was like NOOOOOO! And figured I just entered it wrong (twice with the confirm).  So today, I created a new database in the app and set the main password again (to what I thought it was before) and created only 2 password files (thankfully), closed the app and tried to log in again with the main password. It again told me I had the wrong password. Which is CRAP I typed it slowly and made sure I had all the correct characters.  What good is an app that I can't get into??
